--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> To do a different pressure, simply change 101325 to the desired  
> pressure setpoint in Pascals.  This function has the effect of  
> expanding the volume whenever the pressure goes slightly above the  
> setpoint, and contracting it when it goes below, thereby forcing 
the  
> pressure to stay very close to the setpoint value.  The 
coefficient  
> should be set to a value large enough so that the pressure 
deviations  
> are sufficiently small, but not so large that numerical problems 
occur.
> 
> Actually, while this all works, reactor_ode.m is the old way of 
doing  
> kinetics simulations.  The new way is to use class Reactor.  There  
> should be examples of how to do this in the 'demo' folder.
> Hope this helps.
> 
> Dave G.
> 
> 
> 
> On Wednesday, June 4, 2003, at 12:59 PM, y2kpac wrote:
> 
> > In the suggested matlab code for the function vdot.m (which is 
called
> > by reactor_ode.m), volume change to keep constant pressure is
> > calculated by
> > v = 1.e11 * (pressure(gas) - 101325);
> > The comments specify that this is valid only for 1 atm.  What 
about
> > isobaric processes at other pressures?  How is the coefficient 
1.e11
> > calculated?  Is it a function of pressure?
> >
> > Paul
> >
